Research shows, for example, that patients' SF-36 scores consistently improve after hip-replacement surgery (for severe arthritis) and prostate surgery (for trouble urinating) when they're done right.

It can't select which questions to ask.

That saves time (the new nursing exam takes less than two hours, on average) and also makes tests more accurate, since the computer can ask more questions around your level to ensure you really are in the 63 rd percentile.

The breakthrough came when test designers (or "psychometricians," as they like to call themselves) programmed computers to select questions based on your previous answers, just as in "." When you get a question right, the computer asks a harder one, and an easier one when you get one wrong.
